Graphical abstract The hierarchical MCM-41/ZSM-5 aluminosilicate synthesized via a double-template procedure using CTAB and TPAOH was applied as a support for Pt and Pd isomerization catalysts with metal loading of 0.5 wt.%. The formation of micro-ZSM-5, as well as meso-MCM-41 phases, was confirmed by XRD, TEM, SEM, and FT-IR. The element composition, textural properties and acidity both of MCM-41/ZSM-5 composite and noble metals supported catalysts were structurally characterized by TGA, N2 sorption, XRF, and NH3-TPD. Examining the catalytic evaluation of MCM-41/ZSM-5 supported Pt and Pd catalysts in hydroisomerization of C8 aromatic fraction in a fixed bed flow-type unit at 280−420 °C, LHSV of 1–6 h−1 and H2:feed of 1200–3600, showed that the Pt catalyst is more active compared to its industrial counterpart and provides high m-xylene and ethylbenzene conversions predominantly with p-xylene formation at 340 °C with LHSV of 1.0 h−1 (H2/feed = 2400) as well as for LHSV of 3.5 h−1 (H2/feed = 1200). Keywords Micro-mesoporous composite Zeolite ZSM-5 Mesoporous silica MCM-41 Hydroisomerization p-xylene 1 Introduction Hydroisomerization of C8 aromatic fraction to p-xylene (PX) is commercially used to produce terephthalic acid that is finally converted to polyethylene terephthalate [1–3]. C8 aromatic feedstock usually consists of a mixture of xylenes (50–60 wt. % of m- and 20–25 wt. % of o- and p-isomers) and about 5−20 wt. % of ethylbenzene (EB) [4]. Recent developments in this process have been focused on the design of the catalysts for selective transformation of all isomers into target PX with minimal xylene losses [5–7]. Isomerization of C8 aromatics is a multistage acid-catalyzed process, initially performed at atmospheric pressure and resulting in a variety of by-products. Later, the process conditions were shifted to higher hydrogen pressure to inhibit side reactions and coke formation [8]. To regulate the reaction pathway, bifunctional noble metal-containing catalysts could be applied for selective EB transformation [9–11]. To control selectivity for valuable products, particularly PX, various porous systems, such as ordered mesoporous aluminosilicates, zeolites, may be applied as supports for isomerization catalysts [12–14]. The most commercialized catalysts are based on zeolites due to their shape selectivity, acid sites density, and high surface area [12,15–17]. Depending on textural properties, two basic reaction mechanisms are possible for gas-phase isomerization of xylenes over solid acidic catalysts: intramolecular (direct isomerization via 1,2-alkyl shift in a benzenium ion) and intermolecular (disproportionation, trimethylbenzene formation followed by transalkylation) [15]. Catalyst textural parameters, such as pore size, quantity, and distribution of acid sites have a great influence on the reaction route and consequently on p/o-xylenes ratio [18]. Thus, ZSM-5 with ten-membered ring pore openings having a high Brønsted acidity and a regular three-dimensional channel structure provides high p/o-selectivity during xylenes isomerization via the intramolecular mechanism [19]. However, the intermolecular isomerization pathway is neglected due to the steric hindrance of trimethylbenzene in the micropores of ZSM-5, since bimolecular reaction mechanism requires larger pore systems [20,21]. The most acknowledged mechanism for EB isomerization into xylenes over mesoporous catalysts via the formation of naphthene intermediates, requires both metal and acid catalyst functions. The reaction pathway proposes the hydrogenation of EB over metal sites resulting in cycloalkanes, while the acid function is required to isomerize the naphthene to methyl-ethyl-substituted five-membered ring species that can further convert to a dimethyl-substituted six-membered ring naphthene, followed by dehydrogenation thereof over metal active sites forming xylene isomers. One more feasible pathway for EB transformation over zeolite-based catalysts is dealkylation either through acid or metal-catalyzed mechanisms, i.e., hydrogenolysis. Other plausible reactions for EB conversion are disproportionation and transalkylation reactions. The former reaction results in the formation of bulky di-ethylbenzene molecules along with benzene molecules. The transalkylation reactions may result in the production of large molecules like dimethylethylbenzene and ethylmethyl benzene, together with the formation of benzene and toluene molecules [22,23]. Compared to microporous materials, large-pore zeolites were found to be a bifunctional component of the catalyst promoting EB conversion mainly into xylenes, whereas EB dealkylation is the main reaction pathway over mesopore pentasil-based catalysts [23–25]. While the pore size in zeolites varies in the range of 3–15 Å [26], mesoporous materials could expand this range to 100 Å or even more [27,28]. Hence, to facilitate both intra- and intermolecular routes, micro-mesoporous materials with bimodal pore distribution may be applied as supports for isomerization catalysts. Thus, so-called "hierarchical zeolites" have been synthesized via bitemplate synthesis using solid templates, soft templates (organosilane surfactants and polymers), or by chemical leaching (desilication and dealumination) [29–31]. Prepared by the template method [32], hierarchical ZSM-5 has higher activity in the alkylation of aromatics [6,32,33], as well as the desilicated counterpart exhibits the higher performance in toluene disproportionation or xylenes isomerization as compared to their microporous analogues [34]. Plenty of efforts have been attempted to combine the advantages both for mesoporous materials and zeolites [2,35,36]. One of the most studied mesoporous silica is MCM-41 (Mobil Composition of Matter No. 41) with the average pore diameter of 35 Å, exceeding the kinetic diameter of trimethylbenzene (7.6–8.6 Å [37]), favors the intermolecular reaction mechanism. MCM-41 is characterized by an unidirectional pore system, long-range hexagonal array, and a high surface area, usually between 750 and 1250 m2/g [38–40]. However, MCM-41 based catalysts have rather low acidity and activity in acid-catalyzed isomerization processes. The acidity of MCM-41 can be increased by isomorphic substitution of Si4+ with Al3+ during the synthesis procedure [28]. But still the main disadvantage of mesoporous Al-MCM-41 is associated with its amorphous framework [26]. Therefore, to form MCM-41/ZSM-5 hierarchical structure, the amorphous framework of Al-MCM-41 should be recrystallized using MFI structure-directing agent such as tetrapropylammonium cations (TPA+). Balasamy et al. investigated the performance of MCM-41/ZSM-5 in m-xylene (MX) isomerization and concluded higher PX selectivity for composite as compared with pure materials. However, the influence of simultaneous presence of micro- and mesopores in hierarchical zeolite-containing materials in catalyst has not been studied for C-8 aromatic cut from an industrial reforming unit [5]. It is worth mentioning that a comparison of catalytic performance for noble metal-containing catalysts based on micro-mesoporous MCM-41/ZSM-5 aluminosilicate and the industrial counterpart in hydroisomerization of C8 aromatic feedstock is not disclosed in the literature. This study is aimed at the synthesis of micro-mesoporous composite consisting of ZSM-5 zeolite and MCM-41 aluminosilicate and investigation of the catalytic performance of this material Pt and Pd supported catalysts in hydroisomerization of industrial C8 aromatic cut depending on the process conditions: temperature, LHSV, and H2:feed volume ratio. To exclude the bias practical operation, also the catalytic activity of the synthesized versus industrial catalysts was compared. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Chemicals The following reagents: sodium hydroxide (NaOH, powder, 99.99 %), fumed silica (SiO2, 99.8 %), sodium aluminate (NaAlO2, powder, 99.95 %), hexadecyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB, ≥99 %), tetrapropylammonium hydroxide solution (TPAOH, 1.0 M in H2O), ammonium nitrate (NH4NO3, ≥98 %), nitric acid (HNO3, 70 %), platinic chloride hexahydrate (H2PtCl6·6H2O, 99.95 %) and palladium (II) chloride (PdCl2, 99 %) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich, boehmite (AlO(OH)·7H2O, Pural SB) was purchased from Sasol. All the chemicals were used without additional purification. 2.2 Synthesis procedures Micro/mesoporous MCM-41/ZSM-5 composite was synthesized by a double-template method based on works [41,42]. At the first step, 0.7 g of NaOH and 5.8 mL of TPAOH were dissolved in 35.5 mL of distilled H2O. The mixture was stirred thoroughly until the complete dissolving of the solid alkali. Then, 6.9 g of fumed silica was added to the obtained solution portionwise, under continuous stirring. The seeding gel was aged at 100 °C for 16 h. Concurrently, 2.2 g of CTAB and 0.4 g of NaOH were dissolved in 43.3 mL of distilled water and stirred until the complete dissolution of the template. Then 0.51 g of sodium aluminate (NaAlO2) was added to the obtained solution and carefully mixed. After that, 4.9 g of fumed silica was added portionwise with stirring. The mixture was stirred for three hours at room temperature. The resulting gel was aged at 100 °C for 16 h. At the second step, the obtained gels were mixed and stirred at room temperature for 1 h and thermostated at 180 °C for 48 h in a teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The resulting gel following composition of Al2O3:47.5SiO2:1.5CTAB:7.5TPAOH:7.5NaOH:1092.5H2O was washed with distilled water, dried at 60 °C and calcined at 550 °C for 5 h. To prepare an active acid form of the material, the resulting sodium form of MCM-41/ZSM-5 was treated with 0.5 M NH4NO3 solution twice. Then the material was washed with distilled water, dried and calcined at 550 °C. To obtain the support for catalysts, pellets (1 mm x 2 mm) were prepared in an extruder using boehmite as a binder and dilute solution of HNO3. The extrudates were dried at 80–140 °C for 6 h, and then calcined at 550 °C for 4 h. After calcination, the catalyst supports contained 70 wt. % of micro-mesoporous aluminosilicate and wt. 30 % of γ-Al2O3. The resulting extrudates were impregnated with hexachloroplatinic acid (H2[PtCl6]) or palladium (II) chloride (PdCl2) by standard incipient wetness technique to achieve Pd and Pt loading of 0.5 wt. % Then, resulting catalysts were dried at 60 °C for 6 h, at 80 °C, 120 °C and 160 °C for 2 h. Afterward, the samples were placed in the reactor and activated in a hydrogen flow (10 mL/min) for Pt and Pd reduction under the following conditions: heating up to 250 °C (2 °C/min), then to 450 °C (10 °C/min) with thermostating for 1 h and 3 h at each temperature, respectively. 2.3 Characterization techniques X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) analysis of the MCM-41/ZSM-5 samples was carried out in a Rigaku SmartLab diffractometer. XRD patterns were recorded between 2θ = 1.5° – 6.0° and 2θ = 1.5° – 50.0°, using Cu Kα =1.54 Å radiation. XRD data obtained were interpreted using Rigaku PDXL software with a powder database. The crystallinity of MFI phase was calculated according to the following formula [43]: C r y s t a l l i n i t y ( % ) = P e a k a r e a b e t w e e n 2 θ = 22 ° - 25 ° o f t h e s a m p l e P e a k a r e a b e t w e e n 2 θ = 22 ° - 25 ° o f t h e r e f e r e n c e M F I s a m p l e * 100 % Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were recorded on a Thermo Scientific™ Nicolet IR2000 spectrometer using multiple distortions of the total internal reflection method with multi-reflection HATR accessories, containing a 45˚ ZnSe crystal for different wavelengths with a resolution of 4 cm−1 in the range of 1500–500 cm−1. 27Al MAS NMR experiments were performed on a Bruker AVANCE-II 400 spectrometer (v(27Al) =104.3 MHz) with 4 mm HX MAS probe and spinning rate 12 kHz. One pulse sequence with π/12 pulse length of 0.8 μs, a recycle delay of 0.2 s, and scans of 1024 were used. The chemical shifts were referenced to Al(NO3)3 (0 ppm). Thermogravimetric analysis and differential scanning calorimetry (TGA-DSC) were performed on a TA Instruments SDT Q600 analyzer with a calorimeter. The sample was put in a platinum crucible and gradually heated to 800 °C with a temperature ramp of 10 °C min−1. All changes in the sample weight were recorded. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was executed using a JEOL JEM-2100 microscope with an electron tube voltage of 200 kV. The samples were prepared by dropwise addition of water dispersions onto formvar grids. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was performed on a JEOL JEM microscope with a JIB-4501 double-beam system (magnification of 5–300000 times) and an image resolution of 2.5 nm at 30 kV. All SEM specimens were sputtered with gold (approximately 5-nm thickness) to ensure their good surface conductivity. More detailed information about the average crystal size and diameters of the channels and metal particle size distribution was revealed by the statistical evaluation of several TEM and SEM images using Image-Pro Plus 7.0 software. Particle size distribution was analyzed using 3–5 micrographs based on the counting of ca 500 particles. The textural characteristics of the samples were determined by low-temperature nitrogen sorption using a Micromeritics Gemini VII system. All the specimens were outgassed at 300 °C for 3 h prior to being analyzed. The specific surface area was calculated by BET method from the amount of nitrogen adsorbed at P/P0 = 0−0.25. The average pore size and micropore surface area were assessed according to the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) and t-plot models. The acidity of the materials and catalysts was evaluated using ammonia temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) procedure on a Micromeritics AutoChem HP2950 instrument. The ammonia adsorption was carried out in a quartz reactor at 60 °C for 30 min. Physically adsorbed NH3 was removed in a nitrogen flow at 100 °C for 30 min. The change of ammonia concentration in the effluent gas, upon heating samples from 100 to 700 °C with a ramp of 10 °C min–1 was analyzed with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) as a function of temperature. The Si/Al molar ratio and metal content in the samples were determined using an energy dispersive X-ray fluorescence (XRF) spectrometer Thermo Scientific ARL Quant'X in a vacuum. The results were processed using the standard-less UniQuant method. Pulse chemisorption of CO was performed in a quartz reactor using AutoChem 2950HP (Micromeritics Instrument Corp.; Norcross, GA, USA). Samples were reduced with H2 at 350 °C for 30 min, purged with He for 30 min, and cooled down to room temperature. A mixture of 3% CO + He (balance) was applied, loop volume was 0.5 mL. Calculations were performed by the formulas below [44]. Metal dispersion was calculated as: D = V s ∙ S F 22414 ∙ M W F ∙ W ∙ 100 % where V s – volume sorbed, cm3 at STP; S F – stoichiometry factor (for CO – 1); W – sample weight, g; F – a fraction of sample weight for the metal; M W – molecular weight of the metal. The surface area was calculated by the formula (per g metal): S m = V s ∙ S F 22414 ∙ W ∙ 6.023 ∙ 10 23 ∙ S A m where S A m is the cross-sectional area for the metal, m2. Surface area per g catalyst was calculated as: S c a t = S A m / F Average particle diameter was calculated as: A P D = 6000 d ∙ D / 100 M W ∙ 6.023 ∙ 10 23 ∙ S A m where d is the metal density, g/cm3. 2.4 Catalytic tests An evaluation of MCM-41/ZSM-5 supported noble-catalysts and the commercially used analogue was undertaken in the isomerization of C8 aromatic fraction from a catalytic reforming unit. The feedstock composition is presented in Table 1 . The catalytic experiments were performed in a flow-type unit with a fixed-bed catalyst (5 mL) under a hydrogen pressure of 1.0 MPa in the temperature range 280−420 °C, liquid hourly space velocity (LHSV) 1.0, 3.0 and 6.0 h−1, H2: feed volume ratio of 1200–3600. The reaction products were taken hourly during the process and analyzed with a gas chromatograph (Chromos GX-1000 with 60 m and 0.32 mm id. MEGA-WAX Spirit capillary column) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID). On-line gas chromatographic analysis was performed on a 50 m × 0.53 mm ValcoPlot VP-Alumina capillary column and on 3 packed columns using a FID and a TCD. The catalytic activity of the prepared materials was determined in terms of MX and EB conversions and selectivities to PX, Benzene, Toluene, and C1-C3 gases. The product concentrations were calculated using a method of internal normalization. MX and EB conversions were calculated as the ratio of MX and EB losses to their initial values in the feed, respectively. PX selectivity was calculated as the ratio of the PX growth (compared to its content in the feed) to the product increments. The gas yield was calculated as a mass decrement between liquid products and feed injected. Each value was measured no less three times with error no more than 1 %. The stability of the catalysts has been evaluated at 340 °C, LHSV =1 h−1 and H2/feed volume ratio = 2400 for 50 h on stream. Afterward, the catalysts were regenerated at 600 °C in air flow for 4 h, then activated in hydrogen and tested again under the same conditions. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Materials characterization The structure of the micro-mesoporous MCM-41/ZSM-5 aluminosilicate obtained by a double-templating pathway was confirmed by XRD (Fig. 1 ). Reflexes in the wide-angle pattern strongly correspond to that one’s observed in diffractogram of conventional H-ZSM-5 in the range of 0°-50° (Fig. 1a), indicating the presence of MFI structure [45]. Reflections arranged in the low-angle area (100, 110, and 200) confirm the presence of a well-ordered hexagonal mesostructure of Al-MCM-41 (Fig. 1b) [36]. The (110) and (200) peaks have low intensity and are broadened due to the introduction of aluminum into the MCM-41 structure [46]. However, all the reflexes are slightly shifted towards the lower 2θ angles, due to joint crystallization of the zeolite and MCM-41, in full accordance with [41]. No other phases apart from MCM-41 and ZSM-5 were indicated. The crystallinity of ZSM-5 phase in MCM-41/ZSM-5 composite is 75.1 %, and we suppose that the rest 24.9 % can be attributed to the MCM-41. The interplanar spacing of the material (Table 2 ) was calculated using the Wulff-Bragg equation by the position of the peaks with the highest intensity in the diffraction pattern: λ =0.154 nm is the wavelength for Ni-filtered Cu Kα-radiation, d is an interplanar distance, θ is a diffraction angle [47]. The results are fully coincident with the data on typical ZSM-5 and MCM-41 [48,49]. The FT-IR profile of the MCM-41/ZSM-5 is depicted in Fig. 2 . The signal near 1217 cm−1 is assigned to the presence of structures containing four chains of 5-membered rings arranged around a two-fold screw axis, characterizing ZSM-5 structure [50]. The absorption band at 1063 cm−1 corresponds to asymmetric SiOSi oscillations and the signal at 778 cm–1 indicates vibrations of symmetric SiOSi bonds in SiO4 tetrahedron [51]. According to [47], the broadened peak at 795 cm–1 is ascribed to the presence of Si linked with Al, and consequently proves the Al-MCM-41 formation, while peaks arranged at 1217 and 541 cm−1 are assigned to the presence of a double five-membered ring of ZSM-5 [52]. Any peaks attributed to CH bonds vibration are absent at 2800−3000 cm−1, indicating the complete removal of organic template [53]. 27Al MAS NMR spectroscopy allowed to determine the coordination of Al atoms in the MCM-41/ZSM-5 lattice. According to the 27Al MAS NMR spectrum, some minor amounts of octahedral aluminum (signal at −0.7 ppm) are present in the sample. But the Al atoms are in a four-coordinated state predominantly (signal at -53.5 ppm) (Fig. 3 a) [41,54]. Moreover, the presence of intensive narrow spinning sidebands (SSB) from quadrupolar satellite transitions (ST) of Al in a four-coordinated state in the spectrum (marked by arrows in Fig. 3b) allows to conclude that the tetrahedral aluminum is mainly situated in well-crystallized MFI phase. This kind of SSB can be observed only for the aluminum situated in unique rigid sites in well-defined crystalline material with minimal variation of site structure parameters (length of bonds and angles between them). Thermogravimetric analysis (Fig. 4 ) was performed to determine the rate of water and template removal from the sample. The weight loss starts from 35 to 200 °C due to the moisture removal. At higher temperatures, significant changes in the sample weight were absent. The absence of others' bending of the heat flow curve confirms the assumption of complete template elimination and material thermal stability [28]. The morphology of MCM-41/ZSM-5 is shown on SEM micrographs (Fig. 5 ). The sample synthesized has double-crystal morphology - ellipsoidal and cuboidal and doesn’t contain any other amorphous or crystalline phases [55]. The resulting globular particles of the MCM-41/ZSM-5 had the average diameter ∼1 μm as shown earlier in [41]. The TEM images of the obtained samples confirm that the micro-mesoporous structure contains zeolite of ZSM-5 type and MCM-41 phases (Fig. 6 ). From the micrographs, well-ordered mesochannel arrays of MCM-41 (on the left picture) and microchannels of ZSM-5 (on the right picture) can be observed. The average diameters of micro- and mesochannels were 0.607 and 4.038 nm, respectively. The nitrogen sorption isotherms of a synthesized micro-mesoporous material, a support formed with boehmite and catalysts are depicted in Fig. 7 . Pristine MCM-41/ZSM-5 is characterized by an isotherm of IV type with a hysteresis loop in the area of the P/P0 ratio of 0.6−0.8, which is typical for mesoporous materials [56,57]. However, at low relative pressure the isotherm curve corresponds to the I type indicating the presence of microporous phase. The material revealed to have rather high specific BET surface area, bi-modal (for MCM-41/ZSM-5) and tri-modal (for support and catalysts) pore size distribution. Following [58], mesopores providing large specific surface area essentially play the role of transport channels allowing an access of reactants and reaction products to/from the catalyst active sites. Meanwhile, micropores are necessary for hydrocarbon conversion and provide higher PX selectivity [59,60]. Adding of alumina (SBET ∼ 231 m2/g and average pore diameter ∼ 62 Å) as a binder and further calcination results in the reduction of specific surface area and increase in the number of mesopores (Table 3 ) [61]. Nonetheless, the nitrogen sorption isotherms of the catalysts are still in between I + IV type (typical for micro-mesoporous materials) [62]. After Pt and Pd deposition the textural characteristics of the supports change insignificantly. The average diameters for micro- and mesopores of the catalysts are about 7 and 61 Å, respectively (Table 3). These results are consistent with the XRD data and TEM images and suggest that all the samples after calcination at 550 °C retain the characteristics of regular and hexagonal pore arrangement of MCM-41-type mesoporous materials and contain micropores. The weighted content of the noble metals deposited was determined by XRF analysis. The resulted catalysts contain 0.47 and 0.45 wt. % of Pt and Pd, respectively, while the amount of active component in the industrial catalyst is 0.41 wt. %. The metals d-spacing obtained from TEM images (Fig. 8 ) processing is 0.217 nm and 0.247 nm for Pt- and Pd-clusters, respectively, which is in full accordance with the theoretical distance values [63,64]. The particle size distribution which was also calculated from the catalysts microphotographs are presented in Fig. 8d and h. The dispersion values calculated from CO-chemosorption analysis are 38.7 and 45.9 % for Pt and Pd, respectively. Before catalytic testing, the acidity of catalysts was determined by NH3-TPD (Fig. 9 , Table 4 ). The NH3-TPD curves for MCM-41/ZSM-5 as well as Pt- and Pd-supported catalysts have two peaks in the ranges of 120−300 °C and 300−700 °C revealing the presence of weak and strong acid sites respectively [65]. The latter is usually attributed to the ammonia desorption from the Brønsted acid sites [66]. Their presence, in turn, is a consequence of four-coordinated Al in the crystal lattice of the material, which was indicated by 27Al NMR. Strong acid sites make the largest contribution both to the xylene disproportionation ensuring the intermolecular isomerization route within the mesopores and to the side dealkylation reactions [67]. Weak acid sites provide alkylation of the aromatic ring and increase PX selectivity [68]. The most studies emphasize maintaining the balance between strong and weak acid sites for optimal isomerization [69]. The addition of alumina at the stage of carrier formation slightly decreases the total acidity, while the strong/weak ratio sharply decreases from 2.64 to 2.02 due to introduction of mostly Lewis acid sites (Table 4) [36,70,71]. After modification with Pt and Pd, the total acidity of both catalysts remains unchanged, while for the palladium one the strong/weak ratio is higher. Such redistribution in acid sites strength may be connected with different values of metal dispersion in the samples, which affects the electron charge of the support oxygen atoms, i.e. the catalyst willingness to donate a proton to adsorbing molecules (the Brønsted acidity) [72]. The total acidity of the industrial catalyst is slightly lower, however, the ratio of strong to weak acid sites is approximately two times higher as compared to the synthesized samples. Moreover, the TPD profile of the industrial sample contains a peak at the range of 500−700 °C, corresponding to superacid sites [73]. 3.2 Catalysis results Generally, industrial gas-phase isomerization processes over bifunctional zeolite-based noble metal-containing catalysts are performed in fixed-bed reactor under hydrogen pressure in the temperature range of 350−450 °C [22,74]. These conditions are based on the thermodynamic equilibrium of xylenes isomerization and hydrogenation as well as thermal cracking of hydrocarbons resulted in the formation of undesirable gases above 450 °C [75]. As for gas-phase isomerization, usually the process is performed under hydrogen pressure of 0.5–1.0 MPa to prevent active metal deactivation, and hydrogen to feed volume ratio of about 1200−2000. An important parameter for the industrial hydroisomerization process is also LHSV, which varies from 1.0 to 8.0 h−1 depending both on the operating temperature and feed composition [76]. Therefore, testing of micro-mesoporous aluminosilicate supported Pt- and Pd- catalysts, as well as the industrial counterpart, was carried out at temperatures of 280−420 °C, hydrogen pressure of 1.0 MPa, H2: feed volume ratio of 1200, and LHSV of 1.0 h−1. The effect of the reaction temperature on MX and EB conversion is presented in Fig. 10 . At temperatures below 300 °C, MX and EB conversion over the industrial catalyst is too low compared to micro-mesoporous supported Pd and Pt ones, meanwhile, the Pt-containing catalyst is more active for EB transformation. Rising temperature up to 320 °C increases sharply EB and MX conversions still exceeding these values for the industrial catalyst. What is more interesting, at the temperatures above 300 °C Pd-based catalyst was found to be the most active for MX transformation. At temperatures higher than 320 °C, the activities of Pt- and Pd- catalysts are similar. The Pt-containing catalyst is more active for EB transformation at 320 °C, finding comparable to Pd one EB conversion in the temperature range of 340−440 °C. As depicted in the charts, EB conversion over MCM-41/ZSM-5-based catalysts attains 100 % at 340 °C remaining unchanged up to 420 °C, while over the industrial sample the same level of transformation attains only at 400 °C and higher. According to the reaction mechanism proposed with the carbocation involved, isomerization of xylenes takes place on acid sites, whereas EB transformation occurs mainly on active metal sites [77]. So, the Pd-based catalyst is more active in MX conversion due to higher acidity with a predominance of strong acid sites compared to the Pt-containing sample (strong/weak = 1.55 vs 1.36, Table 4). In terms of the industrial isomerization process, the most undesirable C8 isomer is EB. It is hardly separated from a xylenes mixture since their boiling points are very close [78]. One of the approaches to exclude EB from a reaction mixture is an application of microporous-based catalysts providing EB destruction via either dealkylation to benzene or isomerization/transalkylation to xylenes [79]. Thus, C8 aromatics isomerization over ZSM-5 zeolite-based catalysts leads to EB conversion up to 85 % through the dealkylation confirmed by high benzene and ethane yields [73]. For mesoporous supported catalysts having a larger pore size as compared to zeolites, EB transforms not only via dealkylation but also through disproportionation [24]. With that, according to the literature data [29,80], highly ordered mesoporous MCM-41 promotes EB disproportionation via carbocation chain mechanism involving benzylic carbocations and diarylmethane intermediates [79]. Xylenes may be also dealkylated immediately or in two stages through toluene forming benzene and methane eventually. For MCM-41/ZSM-5-based catalysts, benzene selectivity is comparable to the industrial one, which is probably proving both EB and MX dealkylation to toluene or benzene over acid sites. Methylbenzene dealkylation over acid sites is exothermic and the reaction occurs at low temperatures, meanwhile active metal sites also affect the reaction pathway and product distribution [12]. At higher temperatures and lower LHSVs, dealkylation takes place with rising reaction rate for long side chain aromatics [81], so EB dealkylation is the main contributor to the benzene formation [10]. It can also be proven by the high C2 content in gaseous products. The toluene selectivity over the Pt-containing catalyst is close to that of the industrial one below 300 °C, but it significantly increases at temperatures above 320 °C (Fig. 11 a). The Pd-containing catalyst exhibits a higher selectivity to toluene and benzene comparing with the Pt-based sample. Meanwhile, the gas yield over the Pd/MCM-41/ZSM-5 at 280 °C is about 5.6 % and increases gradually with temperature, but doesn’t exceed 10 % at 400 °C (Fig. 11b–d). For the Pt/MCM-41/ZSM-5 catalyst, the gas yield starts from 8% at 260 °C and reaches 13.5 % at the temperature of 400 °C. This catalyst demonstrates higher selectivity to C2 gases at the temperature above 280 °C which is in full accordance with its activity in MX and EB transformation through dealkylation. For the industrial catalyst, the curve of gas yield vs temperature rapidly rises approximately from 4.4 % (280 °C) to 9.9 % (380 °C), and being constant at 420 °C. This catalyst demonstrates higher selectivity to C1 gas as compared to the Pd-supported one. The latter also provides a higher C3 yield, in particular at 280−320 °C, formed through MX disproportionation and transalkylation/isomerization to trimethylbenzene or isopropylbenzene according to intermolecular reaction pathway in mesopores followed by dealkylation to benzene and C3 gaseous products. The m-, p- and o-xylenes isomerization rapidly attains equilibrium that is slightly temperature dependent [82]. While MX forms due to alkyl migration at high temperatures, PX is the main product at low temperatures. At the same time, due to the support’s mesoporosity, complementary metal and acid sites appear, being available for bulky molecules that are actually too large to diffuse into the microporous structure [83]. These mesoporous transport channels favor the intermolecular reaction pathway via MX disproportionation, trimethylbenzene formation, and its further transalkylation to PX [15]. Besides, EB isomerization takes place on the active metal sites (Pt or Pd) being available to bulky molecules suggesting EB hydrogenation to ethylcyclohexane followed by its two-stage isomerization first to ethylmetylcyclopentane and further to 1,2-dyethylcyclohexane afterword dehydrogenation forming OX. The Pt and Pd supported MCM-41/ZSM-5 catalysts exhibited lower selectivity to PX, while p/o-xylenes ratio is approximately the same compared to the commercial catalyst (Fig. 12 ). At the same time, PX selectivity as well as p/o-xylenes ratio over the Pt-containing catalyst are close to the equilibrium and exceed these parameters for the Pd-based one. The PX selectivity and p/o-xylenes ratio decrease dramatically above 340 °C. It means that EB and MX dealkylation as well as EB hydrogenation over active metal sites are predominant processes. At temperatures below 320 °C, exothermic methylbenzene dealkylation over acid sites occurs [84]. The C9 aromatic compounds, predominantly 1,2,4-trimethylbenzene (1,2,4-TMB) were also detected in the reaction products (Fig. 13 ). Moreover, the catalysts based on MCM-41/ZSM-5 composite favor the formation of the C9 aromatic with higher selectivity comparing to the industrial counterpart due to the implementation of the intermolecular mechanism within mesopores. However, the total amount of 1,2,4-TMB is relatively low (selectivity within 1%), which is most likely due to its dealkylation into BTX mixture in micropores of ZSM-5 [85]. The product distribution through EB and xylenes dealkylation is also regulated by LHSV, while H2:feed volume ratio provides active metal sites regeneration thereby affecting EB hydrogenation followed by isomerization and OX formation. Optimization of the reaction conditions to maximize EB and MX transformation as well as to enhance PX selectivity and p/o-xylenes ratio as high as at the equilibrium was performed for the Pt-supported MCM-41/ZSM-5 catalyst chosen based on experimental data. On rising LHSV within H2/feed volume ratio being constant, conversions of MX and EB decrease (Fig. 14 ). At 6 h−1 and H2/feed volume ratio of 3600 conversions of EB and MX are minimal, while p/o-xylenes ratio, being the same as at 1200, exceeds value obtained at 2400. While at H2/feed volume ratio of 1200 and 3600 p/o-xylenes ratio differs little and becomes an equal at LHSV of 6.0 h−1, at 2400 it decreases with the LHSV rising, but still remains close to the equilibrium. The highest p/o-xylenes ratio is achieved at H2/feed volume ratio of 2400 and LHSV of 1.0 h−1. In this case, the high selectivity to PX may be explained by two main reasons. First, over small pores of ZSM-5 MX transforms to more compact PX molecules having higher diffusivity compared to o-isomer and easily escaping via the zeolite channel system [86]. Secondly, mesopores are found to provide the intermolecular route involving MX disproportionation forming diarylmethane followed by bulky trimethylbenzene or isopropylbenzene formation with further isomerization-transalkylation to PX [15]. At 3.5 h−1 on rising the H2/feed volume ratio to 2400 and 3600, p/o-xylenes ratio decreases mainly due to EB isomerization to OX over metal active sites. Thus, at 340 °C the optimal parameters for high MX and EB conversion with predominantly PX formation are both LHSV of 1.0 h-1 at H2/feed volume ratio of 2400 and LHSV of 3.5 h−1 at H2/feed volume ratio of 1200. The evaluation of catalytic activity under time on stream conditions proved the high stability of the composite supported noble metal-based catalysts. Thus, the conversions after 50 h on stream decreased only by approximately 0.5 % both for MX and EB proving high catalysts stability. After oxidative regeneration and activation with hydrogen, the activity of the catalysts remains unchanged. The textural parameters of the catalysts are practically identical to the fresh samples (Table 3), and the acidity was slightly shifted to the strong acid sites decrease (Table 4). 4 Conclusion The micro-mesoporous MCM-41/ZSM-5 composite was synthesized by a double-template method using CTAB and TPAOH as structure-directing agents. The formation of micro-ZSM-5 and meso-MCM-41 phases was confirmed by XRD and IR analyses. The synthesized sample has a double-crystal morphology – ellipsoidal and cuboidal – and doesn’t contain any other amorphous or crystalline phases. According to the TEM data, the resulting globular particles of the MCM-41/ZSM-5 had an average diameter of ∼ 1 μm. From the micrographs, well-ordered mesochannel arrays of MCM-41 and microchannels of ZSM-5 with the average diameters of 4.038 and 0.607 nm, respectively, can be clearly observed. The resulting MCM-41/ZSM-5 composite was used as a support for isomerization catalysts containing 0.47 and 0.45 wt. % of Pt and Pd, respectively, prepared by a standard incipient wetness technique. According to the nitrogen sorption measurements for these catalysts, the isotherms are in between I + IV type and typical for micro-mesoporous materials. The average diameters for micro- and mesopores of the catalysts are about 7 and 61 Å, respectively. Evaluation of Pt and Pd micro-mesoporous aluminosilicate supported catalysts in hydroisomerization of C8 aromatic fraction was carried out in a fixed-bed flow-type unit at temperatures of 280−420 °C, liquid hourly space velocities of 1−6 h−1 and H2:feed volume ratios of 1200–3600. According to the experimental data, these Pt and Pd supported micro-mesoporous MCM-41/ZSM-5 catalysts were found to be more active in EB and MX transformation compared to the industrial one and provide high p/o-xylenes ratio close to the equilibrium. The higher acidity and strong/weak sites ratio for Pd-based catalyst favor MX dealkylation to toluene or benzene confirmed by C1 and C2 content in gaseous products. The Pt-containing catalyst is more active for EB hydroisomerization to OX over metal active sites being available for bulky molecules due to mesopores with lower selectivity to benzene and higher p/o-xylenes ratio. At 280−320 °C, LHSV =1.0 h−1 and H2:feed volume ratio = 1200 (under hydrogen pressure of 1.0 MPa) both catalysts provide high C3 concentration, in particular, formed through MX disproportionation and transalkylation/isomerization to trimethylbenzene or isopropylbenzene according to intermolecular reaction pathway in mesopores followed by dealkylation to benzene. EB conversion over MCM-41/ZSM-5-based catalysts reaches 100 % at 340 °C remaining unchanged up to 420 °C, while over the industrial sample the same conversion attains only at 400 °C and higher. The PX selectivity and p/o-xylenes ratio decrease dramatically above 340 °C. It means that EB and MX dealkylation and EB hydrogenation over metal active sites of MCM-41/ZSM-5-based catalysts are predominant processes. Thus, the optimal temperature range to minimize gas yield maintaining high EB and MX conversion is 320−340 °C. The products distribution and yield of gas formed through EB and xylenes dealkylation are also regulated by LHSV, while H2:feed volume ratio provides active metal sites regeneration thereby affecting EB hydrogenation followed by isomerization and OX formation. At 340 °C the optimal parameters for high MX and EB conversions with predominantly PX formation over more active Pt-catalyst are both LHSV of 1.0 h−1 at H2/feed volume ratio of 2400 and LHSV of 3.5 h−1 at H2/feed volume ratio of 1200. These micro-mesoporous MCM-41/ZSM-5-based Pt- and Pd-catalysts are stable at operating conditions no less than for 50 h and were found to be more active as compared to the industrial one and could be easily scaled up. coredata.dc:description: The hierarchical MCM-41/ZSM-5 aluminosilicate synthesized via a double-template procedure using CTAB and TPAOH was applied as a support for Pt and Pd isomerization catalysts with metal loading of 0.5 wt.%. The formation of micro-ZSM-5, as well as meso-MCM-41 phases, was confirmed by XRD, TEM, SEM, and FT-IR. The element composition, textural properties and acidity both of MCM-41/ZSM-5 composite and noble metals supported catalysts were structurally characterized by TGA, N2 sorption, XRF, and NH3-TPD. Examining the catalytic evaluation of MCM-41/ZSM-5 supported Pt and Pd catalysts in hydroisomerization of C8 aromatic fraction in a fixed bed flow-type unit at 280−420 °C, LHSV of 1–6 h−1 and H2:feed of 1200–3600, showed that the Pt catalyst is more active compared to its industrial counterpart and provides high m-xylene and ethylbenzene conversions predominantly with p-xylene formation at 340 °C with LHSV of 1.0 h−1 (H2/feed = 2400) as well as for LHSV of 3.5 h−1 (H2/feed = 1200).
coredata.dc:title: Micro-mesoporous MCM-41/ZSM-5 supported Pt and Pd catalysts for hydroisomerization of C-8 aromatic fraction
